awd_titl_txt: On the Dynamics of Nonlinear Systems in Applied Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
The analysis of multiphase flow models, such as models governing fluid-particle interaction and evolution of cells, is relevant to several practical applications in engineering and in physical and biomedical sciences. This project focuses on issues of stability, uniqueness and regularity, and numerical approximations for nonlinear models. In particular, the projects include analyzing systems involving moving domains or free boundaries and systems with stochastic forcing. The project includes undergraduates, graduate students, and post-doctoral associates in the research. 

This research project focuses on the modeling and mathematical analysis of nonlinear systems arising in physical and biological science and addresses themes in two interconnected directions: (a) hydrodynamic models within moving domains and free boundary problems, and (b) random perturbations of models of compressible fluids and multiphase flows. The mathematical analysis of these nonlinear models requires innovative ideas for the construction of suitable schemes for the approximation of their governing systems, as well as the development of new analytical techniques for the proof of well-posedness and convergence results in light of special features of the models that arise in applications. The goal of the project is the development of a variational framework able to treat a large class of multi-phase flows both analytically and computationally. The nonlinear systems under investigation include models of compressible fluids governed by the Navier-Stokes and Euler systems, Euler-kinetic fluid models, mixed-type hyperbolic-elliptic systems within fixed or moving domains, and free-boundary models.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The analysis of multiphase flow models, such as models governing fluid-particle interaction and evolution of cells, is relevant to several practical applications in engineering and in physical and biomedical sciences. This project focuses on issues of stability, uniqueness and regularity, and numerical approximations for nonlinear models. In particular, the projects include analyzing systems involving moving domains or free boundaries and systems with stochastic forcing. The project includes undergraduates, graduate students, and post-doctoral associates in the research. 

This research project focuses on the modeling and mathematical analysis of nonlinear systems arising in physical and biological science and addresses themes in two interconnected directions: (a) hydrodynamic models within moving domains and free boundary problems, and (b) random perturbations of models of compressible fluids and multiphase flows. The mathematical analysis of these nonlinear models requires innovative ideas for the construction of suitable schemes for the approximation of their governing systems, as well as the development of new analytical techniques for the proof of well-posedness and convergence results in light of special features of the models that arise in applications. The goal of the project is the development of a variational framework able to treat a large class of multi-phase flows both analytically and computationally. The nonlinear systems under investigation include models of compressible fluids governed by the Navier-Stokes and Euler systems, Euler-kinetic fluid models, mixed-type hyperbolic-elliptic systems within fixed or moving domains, and free-boundary models.

 

Intellectual merit: The mathematical analysis of the nonlinear models in the proposed research requires (a) innovative ideas for the construction of suitable schemes for the approximation of their governing systems; and (b) the development of new analytical techniques for the proof of well-posedness and convergence results in light of the special features in the models as arisein applications: moving domain, free boundary, stochastic forces. The goal of the project is thedevelopment of a variational framework able to treat a large class of multi-phase  flows both analytically and computationally. Progress in the direction of the proposed research will contribute to the further investigation of a wide variety of important physical systems and to the design of higperformance computational algorithms.

Broader impact: The analysis of multiphase  flow models (such as polymeric flows and fluid-particle interaction models) is relevant to several practical applications in engineering, biomedical sciences and medicine. The project includes a substantial educational component as it involves three graduate students and one postdoc. Special attention is given to outreach activities, and to developing programs that foster and encourage training in the  fields of applied mathematics.

 

A short description of the outcomes delivered as part of this investigation:

1.     Hydrodynamic Models within Moving Domains and Free Boundary Problems

Main outcomes 

·       On Hele-Shaw-type systems for the evolution of cells: Large-data existence theory. Convergence and stability of numerical algorithms for their approximations; 

·       On diffusive models within moving domains: The problem of well-posedness; 

·       On a free boundary problem for polymeric fluids: Global existence of weak solutions;

·       Self-organized dynamics. A new model for quorum Sensing was presented and analyzed,

·       On the dynamics of quantum fluids. Modeling and analysis of a two-phase flow of quantum fluids. 

2.     Random perturbations of models of compressible fluids & multiphase flows

Main outcomes: 

·       On viscous heat conducting compressible fluids with stochastic forcing. The global existence of finite-energy weak martingale solutions for large initial data;  Investigation of singular limits in physical regimes of interest; 

·       Characterization of invariant measures for stochastic compressible flows; 

 

In the period 2016-2021 the PI produced 5 Ph.D. (Math Genealogy Project)

 


Last Modified: 10/26/2021
Modified by: Konstantina Trivisa

·       Characterization of invariant measures for stochastic compressible flows;
